title: Case 2
boardPrompt: An adult presents with acute cough and mild dyspnea after recent surgery. A PA chest radiograph is provided.
expectedAnswer:
Diagnosis: Right lower lobe (RLL) collapse (atelectasis).

Key: On PA view, there is increased triangular/retrocardiac opacity projecting over the medial/inferior right lung with **loss of the right hemidiaphragm silhouette** (silhouette sign). The right heart border is **preserved** (argues against RML collapse). There are secondary signs of **volume loss** including crowding of the right lower lobe vessels and slight right hemidiaphragm elevation. On the lateral view, there is **wedge-like retrocardiac opacity** with **inferior/posterior displacement of the major fissure** consistent with RLL volume loss.

Differential: RLL consolidation/pneumonia (less volume loss, air bronchograms; silhouette of diaphragm can also be lost), aspiration in the dependent lower lobe, pleural effusion layering posteriorly (meniscus, blunting) rather than true parenchymal collapse, endobronchial obstruction (mucus plug most common post-op; less commonly tumor/foreign body).

Management: Correlate clinically and compare priors. Encourage pulmonary toilet (incentive spirometry), treat underlying cause (e.g., bronchodilators, mucolytics). If persistent or severe atelectasis, consider **bronchoscopy** to remove mucus plug or evaluate for obstructing lesion. If infection suspected, manage for pneumonia. Document resolution on follow-up imaging.
rubric: Names the finding as right lower lobe collapse/atelectasis.
Correctly identifies **loss of the right hemidiaphragm silhouette** on PA view (silhouette sign).
Notes **preserved right heart border** (helps exclude right middle lobe collapse).
Describes **retrocardiac triangular/wedge opacity** and **major fissure displacement on lateral**.
Mentions **volume loss signs** (vessel crowding, fissure shift, diaphragm elevation).
Provides appropriate **differential** (pneumonia vs. aspiration vs. effusion vs. endobronchial obstruction).
Recommends **pulmonary toilet** and **bronchoscopy if persistent/obstructing lesion suspected**.

questions.stem: On the PA view, which silhouette loss most strongly supports right lower lobe collapse?

choices.explain: RLL is adjacent to the diaphragm; its collapse obscures the right hemidiaphragm. RML collapse more often obscures the right heart border.

questions.stem: Which lateral-view feature best supports right lower lobe volume loss?

choices.text: Anterior displacement of the major fissure

choices.explain: RLL collapse pulls the major fissure posteriorly/inferiorly and creates a wedge-like retrocardiac opacity.

choices.text: Superior displacement of the minor fissure
Diffuse interstitial thickening sparing the retrosternal space

questions.stem: A common immediate cause of right lower lobe atelectasis in a postoperative patient is:

choices.explain: Postoperative mucus plugging can obstruct a lobar bronchus, leading to rapid lobar collapse.

questions.stem: Which finding helps distinguish right middle lobe collapse from right lower lobe collapse on the PA view?

Right middle lobe collapse obscures the right heart border
choices.explain: RML silhouette sign involves the right heart border, whereas RLL collapse more often obscures the right hemidiaphragm with the right heart border preserved.

choices.text: Right lower lobe collapse obscures the right heart border

choices.explain: First-line measures for lobar atelectasis.
Indicated if collapse persists to remove mucus plug or rule out obstructing lesion.

title: Case 4
boardPrompt: A 35-year-old patient is referred for evaluation of recurrent nephrolithiasis.
expectedAnswer: Diagnosis: Medullary nephrocalcinosis. Key: echogenic medullary pyramids with shadowing on ultrasound; cortical sparing. Differential: primary hyperparathyroidism, medullary sponge kidney, distal (type 1) renal tubular acidosis, hypervitaminosis D, sarcoidosis. Management: address underlying metabolic cause; nephrology referral.
rubric: names medullary nephrocalcinosis
describes echogenic renal pyramids
mentions posterior acoustic shadowing
notes cortical sparing
provides a short differential (e.g., hyperparathyroidism, medullary sponge kidney, distal RTA, hypervitaminosis D, sarcoidosis)
recommends further metabolic evaluation or nephrology referral

questions.stem: Which sonographic finding is most characteristic of medullary nephrocalcinosis?

choices.text: Echogenic medullary pyramids with or without posterior acoustic shadowing
choices.explain: Calcifications deposit in the renal medulla/pyramids, producing echogenic pyramids; shadowing may or may not be present depending on burden and equipment.
This pattern is more typical of medical renal disease/CKD affecting the cortex, not medullary calcification.
Hydronephrosis reflects collecting system dilation/obstruction, not medullary calcium deposition.
Cortical calcifications point away from medullary nephrocalcinosis.

questions.stem: Which underlying conditions are classically associated with medullary nephrocalcinosis? (Select all that apply.)

choices.explain: Hypercalcemia/hypercalciuria promote medullary calcium deposition.
Distal RTA causes alkaline urine and hypocitraturia, favoring calcium precipitation in the medulla.
Ectatic collecting ducts predispose to stasis and calcification within the pyramids.
Alport syndrome can cause cortical, not medullary, nephrocalcinosis.
Glomerular diseases like MCD are not typical causes of medullary calcification.

questions.stem: Which feature favors medullary nephrocalcinosis over isolated nephrolithiasis on ultrasound?

choices.text: Multiple pyramids bilaterally show linear/bandlike increased echogenicity
choices.explain: Nephrocalcinosis affects many pyramids, often bilaterally; stones are discrete foci.

choices.text: A single discrete echogenic focus with clean acoustic shadowing in the ureter
choices.explain: This describes a ureteral stone rather than diffuse medullary calcification.

choices.text: Focal mural echogenicity of the bladder
choices.explain: Unrelated to medullary calcification.

choices.text: Absence of twinkle artifact on color Doppler
choices.explain: Twinkle artifact commonly occurs behind calcifications in both stones and nephrocalcinosis.

questions.stem: On color Doppler, which artifact is most commonly seen posterior to calcified foci?

choices.explain: Twinkle artifact is typical behind strongly reflecting calcified interfaces.
Mirror artifact relates to strong specular reflectors like the diaphragm, not calcifications per se.
A short reverberation artifact; classic for adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder, not renal medullary calcifications.
Occurs at the margins of curved structures; not the hallmark finding here.

questions.stem: A 35-year-old with ultrasound showing echogenic medullary pyramids and cortical sparing is otherwise stable. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.explain: Intervention is for obstructing stones, not diffuse medullary calcification.
Nephrocalcinosis warrants evaluation for a metabolic/structural cause.

choices.text: Nephrology referral and targeted metabolic evaluation
choices.explain: Management is directed at the underlying disorder (e.g., hyperparathyroidism, distal RTA).
No role in medullary nephrocalcinosis without an immune/inflammatory indication.

title: Case 5
boardPrompt: A 75-year-old male presents with acute right scrotal pain and swelling, low-grade fever, and dysuria.
expectedAnswer: Diagnosis: Acute right epididymitis with suspected pyocele (complex, multiseptated peritesticular fluid). Key findings: right epididymal enlargement and heterogeneous echotexture; marked hyperemia on color Doppler; multiseptated fluid collection consistent with pyocele; contralateral left epididymal tail appears normal for comparison. No sonographic features of torsion (testicular arterial/venous flow preserved). Management: contact the ordering provider and recommend urologic consultation and antibiotics.

title: Case 6
boardPrompt: 35-year-old female with progressive dysmenorrhea and heavy, prolonged menses.
expectedAnswer: Findings are most consistent with adenomyosis. The uterus is notable for heterogeneous myometrium and multiple small subendometrial cysts near the junctional zone. There are subtle linear striations extending from the endometrium into the myometrium. The endometrium is not abnormally thickened. The uterus may be mildly globular. No discrete intramural mass or calcifications to suggest a focal fibroid. Correlate with symptoms; consider MRI if uncertain or for pre-procedural planning. Management may include hormonal therapy (e.g., LNG-IUD) depending on fertility considerations.
rubric: Identifies heterogeneous myometrium
Mentions subendometrial cysts near the junctional zone
Describes fan-shaped shadowing, venetian-blind shadowing, or linear striations
Differentiates from fibroid (no discrete mass, ill-defined borders)
Suggests appropriate next steps (symptom correlation, MRI if needed, medical therapy)
